hints_raw: Split the vector on the right into a sum of three vectors, separated by ''x'', ''y'', ''z'', then take the vectors as the columns of your matrix ''S''.
question: A 18
sols_html:
Using the hint, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} S\left( \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} \right) = \begin{bmatrix} -y + z \\ x + y + z \\ -x - 2y \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ x \\ -x \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} -y \\ y \\ -2y \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} z \\ z \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = x\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} + y\begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Using these as our column vectors, we arrive at

\[\begin{aligned} S = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \\ -1 & -2 & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Find the matrix for the linear transformation \(S : \mathbb{R}^{3} \to \mathbb{R}^{3}\) given by

\[\begin{aligned} S\left( \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} \right) = \begin{bmatrix} -y + z \\ x + y + z \\ -x - 2y \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]
